comment_text.mn84:1.1: The fact that the Buddha is not mentioned usually signifies a discourse set after his passing, which is confirmed towards the end of this sutta.
comment_text.mn84:1.2: Madhurā (Sanskrit Mathurā), located on the north-western trade route, between modern Agra and Delhi, was the capital of Sūrasena. Painted Grey Ware at the site attests to its settlement in the Vedic era, long before the Buddha’s day with its characteristic Northen Black Polished Ware, which is also found there. Early suttas place the Buddha on the road to Madhurā (AN 4.43), and attribute one short sutta where he complained about how bad it was (AN 5.220). SA 36 in Chinese translation places him at the Umbrella Mango Tree Park on the bank of the Bhadra River, where he gave a discourse whose Pali parallel is in Sāvatthī (SN 22.43). Despite its minor role in early Buddhism, it soon became a major Buddhist center, and as spiritual home of the great arahants Śaṇavāsin, Upagupta, and Moggaliputtatissa played a major role in spreading Buddhism.
comment_text.mn84:2.1: Avanti’s northern capital Ujjeni lay 600km south of Madhurā. The commentary explains that the former king of Madhurā (perhaps the Subāhu of Lalitavistara 3.24 = Vaidya 16 who ruled when the Bodhisatta was born) had married the sister of Pajjota, king of Avanti, hence their son was named “Son of Avanti”. The unification of their houses was, according to the Purānas, in fact a reunification, as both descended from the lunar Yadava lineage. The Yadavas were said to have settled as far as the key port on the Arabian sea at Dvāraka. Avantiputta, however, is not attested outside of this sutta, for which the Chinese parallel says rather, “the king of Mathurā, a western prince”.
comment_text.mn84:4.1: Kaccāna appears in Madhurā also at AN 2.38, where he has a discussion on a similar topic with the brahmin Kandarāyana. Kaccāna often stayed at Avanti, both before and after the Buddha’s passing, where he also dealt with the question of the status of the brahmins (SN 35.132). The commentary says he was in fact the son of the chief priest (purohita) of Avanti, which would explain his connection with Avanti, his discussions on the topic of brahminhood, and his skill in analyzing scripture. Kaccāna ultimately established Buddhism in the region, from where it was later brought to Sri Lanka by another “son of Avanti”, the great monk Mahinda.
comment_text.mn84:4.5: “True-born” is orasa, signifying a natural heir to a legitimately married couple (Manusmṛti 9.159, Skandapurāṇa 223.5, Kauṭilya’s Arthaśāstra 3.7). The literal translation “bosom sons” is tempting, but “bosom” in English conveys intimacy and comfort rather than legitimacy. While putta can mean “son” or “child”, in this case the gendered sense is required, since in Brahmanical context the concept is intended to explain how the male child takes precedence in inheritance (Manusmṛti 9.134).
comment_text.mn84:5.35: Then as now, it would seem, wealth trumps birth.
comment_text.mn84:9.19: This verse is also at DN 27:3.6 and MN 93:5.4. | For “best class” (seṭṭho vaṇṇo) see varṇaśreṣṭhaḥ at Mahābhārata 1.24.4c.
comment_text.mn84:9.20: Mahābhārata 12.181.5 says that brahmins are the white class, aristocrats red, peasants yellow, and menials black. Underlying this is an assumption of the superiority of the fair-skinned northerners of Indo-Aryan descent over the dark-skinned natives (see DN 3:1.10.3).
comment_text.mn84:9.21: I cannot trace this statement to Brahmanical texts, and indeed they have a strong tendency to push back against the idea that only brahmins can find purity.
comment_text.mn84:9.22: An allusion to the famous Puruṣasūkta (Rig Veda 10.90.12): “His (the cosmic Man’s) mouth became the brahmin, his arms became the ruler (rājanya, an alternate name for the khattiyas), his thighs became the peasant (vaiśya); the menial (sūdra) was born from his feet.” This belongs to the latest portion of the Rig Veda, and probably represents a time when the system of four castes was established in the late Vedic period, some centuries before the Buddha. Apart from this, the Rig Veda hardly mentions any of these as castes, let alone all four together.

translation_text.mn84:1.2: At one time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying near Madhurā, in the Nut Grass Grove.
translation_text.mn84:2.2: “It seems the ascetic Kaccāna is staying near Madhurā, in the Nut Grass Grove.
translation_text.mn84:2.4: ‘He is astute, competent, clever, learned, a brilliant speaker, eloquent, mature, a perfected one.’
translation_text.mn84:2.5: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
translation_text.mn84:3.1: And then King Avantiputta had the finest carriages harnessed. He mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out in full royal pomp from Madhurā to see Mahākaccāna.
translation_text.mn84:3.2: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached Mahākaccāna on foot. They exchanged greetings, and when the greetings and polite conversation were over, the king sat down to one side and said to Mahākaccāna:
translation_text.mn84:4.2: ‘Only brahmins are the best class; other classes are inferior.
translation_text.mn84:4.3: Only brahmins are the light class; other classes are dark.
translation_text.mn84:4.4: Only brahmins are purified, not others.
translation_text.mn84:4.5: Only brahmins are the true-born sons of divinity, born from his mouth, born of divinity, created by divinity, heirs of divinity.’
translation_text.mn84:4.6: What does the worthy Kaccāna have to say about this?”
translation_text.mn84:5.1: “Great king, that’s just hearsay in the world.
translation_text.mn84:5.6: And here’s a way to understand that it’s just hearsay in the world.
translation_text.mn84:5.9: What do you think, great king?
translation_text.mn84:5.10: Suppose an aristocrat prospers in money, grain, silver, or gold. Wouldn’t there be aristocrats, brahmins, peasants, and menials who would get up before him and go to bed after him, and be obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely?”
translation_text.mn84:5.35: a menial prospers in money, grain, silver, or gold. Wouldn’t there be menials, aristocrats, brahmins, and peasants who would get up before him and go to bed after him, and be obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely?”
translation_text.mn84:5.44: If this is so, are the four classes equal or not?
translation_text.mn84:5.45: Or how do you see this?”
translation_text.mn84:5.46: “Certainly, worthy Kaccāna, in this case these four classes are equal.
translation_text.mn84:5.47: I can’t see any difference between them.”
translation_text.mn84:5.48: “And here’s another way to understand that the claims of the brahmins are just hearsay in the world.
translation_text.mn84:6.1: What do you think, great king?
translation_text.mn84:6.2: Take an aristocrat who kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct; uses speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; and is covetous, malicious, and has wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, would they be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell, or not?
translation_text.mn84:6.3: Or how do you see this?”
translation_text.mn84:6.4: “Such an aristocrat would be reborn in a bad place.
translation_text.mn84:6.5: That’s what I think, but I’ve also heard it from the perfected ones.”
translation_text.mn84:6.7: It’s good that you think so, and it’s good that you’ve heard it from the perfected ones.
translation_text.mn84:6.8: What do you think, great king?
translation_text.mn84:6.11: a menial who kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct; uses speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; and is covetous, malicious, and has wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, would they be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell, or not?
translation_text.mn84:6.12: Or how do you see this?”
translation_text.mn84:6.13: “Such a brahmin, peasant, or menial would be reborn in a bad place.
translation_text.mn84:6.14: That’s what I think, but I’ve also heard it from the perfected ones.”

translation_text.mn84:6.20: “Certainly, worthy Kaccāna, in this case these four classes are equal.

translation_text.mn84:7.1: What do you think, great king?
translation_text.mn84:7.2: Take an aristocrat who doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, or commit sexual misconduct. They don’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re contented, kind-hearted, with right view. When their body breaks up, after death, would they be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm, or not?
translation_text.mn84:7.3: Or how do you see this?”
translation_text.mn84:7.4: “Such an aristocrat would be reborn in a good place.
translation_text.mn84:7.5: That’s what I think, but I’ve also heard it from the perfected ones.”
translation_text.mn84:7.7: It’s good that you think so, and it’s good that you’ve heard it from the perfected ones.
translation_text.mn84:7.8: What do you think, great king?
translation_text.mn84:7.9: Take a brahmin, peasant, or menial who doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, or commit sexual misconduct. They don’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re contented, kind-hearted, with right view. When their body breaks up, after death, would they be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm, or not?
translation_text.mn84:7.10: Or how do you see this?”
translation_text.mn84:7.11: “Such a brahmin, peasant, or menial would be reborn in a good place.
translation_text.mn84:7.12: That’s what I think, but I’ve also heard it from the perfected ones.”
translation_text.mn84:7.14: It’s good that you think so, and it’s good that you’ve heard it from the perfected ones.

translation_text.mn84:7.16: If this is so, are the four classes equal or not?
translation_text.mn84:7.17: Or how do you see this?”
translation_text.mn84:7.18: “Certainly, worthy Kaccāna, in this case these four classes are equal.
translation_text.mn84:7.19: I can’t see any difference between them.”
translation_text.mn84:7.20: “And here’s another way to understand that the claims of the brahmins are just hearsay in the world.
translation_text.mn84:8.1: What do you think, great king?
translation_text.mn84:8.2: Take an aristocrat who breaks into houses, plunders wealth, steals from isolated buildings, commits highway robbery, and commits adultery. Suppose your men arrest him and present him to you, saying:
translation_text.mn84:8.3: ‘Your Majesty, this man is a bandit, a criminal.
translation_text.mn84:8.5: What would you do to him?”
translation_text.mn84:8.6: “I would have him executed, fined, or banished, or dealt with as befits the crime.
translation_text.mn84:8.8: Because he’s lost his former status as an aristocrat, and is just reckoned as a bandit.”
translation_text.mn84:8.10: Take a brahmin, peasant, or menial who breaks into houses, plunders wealth, steals from isolated buildings, commits highway robbery, and commits adultery. Suppose your men arrest him and present him to you, saying:
translation_text.mn84:8.11: ‘Your Majesty, this man is a bandit, a criminal.
translation_text.mn84:8.13: What would you do to him?”
translation_text.mn84:8.14: “I would have him executed, fined, or banished, or dealt with as befits the crime.
translation_text.mn84:8.16: Because he’s lost his former status as a brahmin, peasant, or menial, and is just reckoned as a bandit.”
translation_text.mn84:8.18: If this is so, are the four classes equal or not?
translation_text.mn84:8.19: Or how do you see this?”
translation_text.mn84:8.20: “Certainly, worthy Kaccāna, in this case these four classes are equal.
translation_text.mn84:8.21: I can’t see any difference between them.”
translation_text.mn84:8.22: “And here’s another way to understand that the claims of the brahmins are just hearsay in the world.
translation_text.mn84:9.1: What do you think, great king?
translation_text.mn84:9.2: Take an aristocrat who shaves off their hair and beard, dresses in ocher robes, and goes forth from the lay life to homelessness. They refrain from killing living creatures, stealing, and lying. They abstain from eating at night, eat in one part of the day, and are chaste, ethical, and of good character.
translation_text.mn84:9.4: “I would bow to them, rise in their presence, or offer them a seat. I’d invite them to accept robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And I’d organize their lawful guarding and protection.
translation_text.mn84:9.6: Because they’ve lost their former status as an aristocrat, and are just reckoned as an ascetic.”
translation_text.mn84:9.8: Take a brahmin, peasant, or menial who shaves off their hair and beard, dresses in ocher robes, and goes forth from the lay life to homelessness. They refrain from killing living creatures, stealing, and lying. They abstain from eating at night, eat in one part of the day, and are chaste, ethical, and of good character.
translation_text.mn84:9.10: “I would bow to them, rise in their presence, or offer them a seat. I’d invite them to accept robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And I’d organize their lawful guarding and protection.
translation_text.mn84:9.12: Because they’ve lost their former status as a brahmin, peasant, or menial, and are just reckoned as an ascetic.”
translation_text.mn84:9.14: If this is so, are the four classes equal or not?
translation_text.mn84:9.15: Or how do you see this?”
translation_text.mn84:9.16: “Certainly, worthy Kaccāna, in this case these four classes are equal.
translation_text.mn84:9.17: I can’t see any difference between them.”
translation_text.mn84:9.18: “This is another way to understand that this is just hearsay in the world:
translation_text.mn84:9.19: ‘Only brahmins are the best class; other classes are inferior.
translation_text.mn84:9.20: Only brahmins are the light class; other classes are dark.
translation_text.mn84:9.21: Only brahmins are purified, not others.
translation_text.mn84:9.22: Only brahmins are divinity’s true-born sons, born from his mouth, born of divinity, created by divinity, heirs of divinity.’”
translation_text.mn84:10.1: When he had spoken, King Avantiputta of Madhurā said to Mahākaccāna,
translation_text.mn84:10.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the worthy Kaccāna has made the teaching clear in many ways.
translation_text.mn84:10.4: I go for refuge to the worthy Kaccāna, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn84:10.5: From this day forth, may the worthy Kaccāna remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
translation_text.mn84:10.6: “Great king, don’t go for refuge to me.
translation_text.mn84:10.7: You should go for refuge to that same Blessed One to whom I have gone for refuge.”
translation_text.mn84:10.8: “But where is that Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”
translation_text.mn84:10.9: “Great king, the Buddha has already become fully quenched.”
translation_text.mn84:11.1: “Worthy Kaccāna, if I heard that the Buddha was within ten leagues, or twenty, or even up to a hundred leagues away, I’d go a hundred leagues to see him.
translation_text.mn84:11.4: But since the Buddha has become fully quenched, I go for refuge to that fully quenched Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn84:11.5: From this day forth, may the worthy Kaccāna remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
